title-group.article-title: The Determinants of Venture Capital Portfolio Size: Empirical Evidence*

permissions.copyright-statement: © 2006 by The University of Chicago. All rights reserved.

abstract.p: This paper explores factors that affect portfolio size among a sample of venture capital financing data from 214 Canadian funds. Four categories of factors affect portfolio size: (1) the venture capital funds’ characteristics, including the type of fund, fund duration, fund‐raising, and the number of venture capital fund managers; (2) the entrepreneurial firms’ characteristics, including stage of development, technology, and geographic location; (3) the nature of the financing transactions, including staging, syndication, and capital structure; and (4) market conditions. The data further indicate decreasing returns to scale in the number of entrepreneurial firms financed by a venture capital fund.

fn.p: I am grateful for comments and suggestions from the seminar participants at the University of Alberta Institute for Financial Research (March and September 2001), the University of Helsinki Venture Capital Congress (October 2001), the University of Amsterdam (January 2002), the Eastern Finance Association (April 2002), and the Babson Entrepreneurship Conference (June 2003). I am indebted to an anonymous referee for very helpful comments and suggestions. I also owe thanks to Felipe Aguerrevere, Scott Crowe, Pengjie Gao, Ari Hyytinen, Josh Lerner, and Ralph Winter for helpful suggestions and to Mary Macdonald and Dmitri Safine for helpful comments and insights into venture capital in Canada. I have also benefited from discussions on related research with Varouj Aivazian, Paul Halpern, Ted Liu, Frank Mathewson, Jeff MacIntosh, and Tom Ross. I am grateful for financial support from the University of Alberta Support for Advancement of Scholarship Fellowship, University of Alberta Pearson Fellowship, and University of British Columbia Entrepreneurship Research Alliance Scholarship and the University of Helsinki. Macdonald & Associates (Toronto) generously provided the data. Contact the author atDouglas@Cumming.com.

sec.label: I.
sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: A very large number of academic papers have addressed the issue of whether scale economies exist among banks (see, e.g., Molyneux, Altunbas, and Gardner [1996] and Berger and Humphrey [1997] for surveys). Research has also compared venture capital to banks (Black and Gilson1998; Landier2002; Ueda2004). Surprisingly, however, academic research has not previously considered the empirical question of efficient size among venture capital organizations. As recent work in the banking literature has explored the impact of risk taking on scale economies (Hughes, Mester, and Moon2001), it is natural to investigate the issue of efficient size for venture capital funds.

The success of the venture capital (VC) and entrepreneurial sectors is regarded important for economic growth and innovation in countries around the world (Gompers and Lerner1999b,2001; Lerner1999,2002a,2002b; Kortum and Lerner2000; Hege, Palomino, and Schwienbacher2003; Gompers, Lerner, and Scharfstein2003). Both theoretical and empirical research is consistent with the proposition that VCs are value‐added investors, typically geographically proximate to their investees, and among the most sophisticated of financial intermediaries at mitigating informational asymmetries and agency costs in financial contracting (e.g., Sahlman1990; Gompers1997; Bergman and Hege1998; Trester1998; Gompers and Lerner1999a,1999b,2000,2001; Kirilenko2001; Schmidt2003; Neus and Walz2005). Much of this work is related to the issue of staging and monitoring VC investments (Gompers1995). This work has recently been extended in important theoretical research on the optimal portfolio of start‐up firms in venture capital (Kanniainen and Keuschnigg [2003,2004]; see also Keuschnigg [2003,2004] and Keuschnigg and Nielsen [2001,2003a,2003b,2004a,2004b] for related theoretical work). Size, diversification, and risk management are particularly important for VC funds. VCs are value‐added but underdiversified investors, since increases in portfolio size dilute the advice provided to each entrepreneur. The efficient size of a VC portfolio balances a trade‐off between diversifying risks with the dilution of value‐added advice, among other things.

This paper builds on the recent theoretical research of Kanniainen and Keuschnigg (2003,2004) on the size of VC portfolios. Many factors are considered herein to capture the essence of value‐added active investment, including the type of VC firm and its number of VC funds, the duration of the VC fund, fund‐raising, the type of entrepreneurial firm (technology, stage of development), and the nature of the financing arrangement (form of finance, staging, and syndication). Nonlinearities are also considered in the theory and empirics in order to test whether returns to scale are increasing or decreasing. A sample of Canadian VC data (source: Macdonald & Associates [Toronto], for the Canadian Venture Capital Association [CVCA]) from 214 VC funds is used to test the new hypotheses developed herein. The evidence provides insight into the optimal portfolio size among different types of VC firms, considering differences among entrepreneurial firms and the nature of the financing transactions.

I consider the determinants of portfolio size in terms of the number of entrepreneurial firms in the VC fund portfolio. The data indicate four main categories of factors that affect portfolio size. First, the type of VC fund and the fund’s characteristics are related to the size of the fund’s portfolio. For example, corporate VCs and private independent limited partnerships have smaller portfolios, whereas government funds (both direct government investment funds and labor‐sponsored funds) have larger portfolios. VC funds that raise more capital and those that have more managers have larger portfolios, but VC funds that are part of VC firms with two or more funds tend to have smaller portfolios. Second, the characteristics of the entrepreneurial firms in the VCs’ portfolios affect portfolio size, including entrepreneurial firm development stage and technology. Larger portfolios are observed among VCs that invest more intensively in early‐stage firms and in life science industries (medical and biotechnology), and VC portfolios are smaller where investment is more intensive in other types of high‐tech industries and among VC funds with a greater proportion of geographically disparate investments. Third, portfolio size depends on the structure and characteristics of the financing transactions. More frequent staging and syndication are associated with smaller portfolios, and VCs that invest a greater proportion of their capital in their investee firms (relative to other investors in the same entrepreneurial firms) have smaller portfolios. Fourth, portfolio sizes are larger among funds that invested over periods of greater returns to stock markets. This latter finding is consistent with seminal evidence provided by Lerner (2002a) on lower rates of VC‐backed innovation in boom periods (for related evidence, see Kortum and Lerner [2000]; for a related theory, see Kanniainen and Keuschnigg [2003,2004] and Keuschnigg [2003,2004]).

I also consider the determinants of portfolio size in terms of the number of entrepreneurial firms in the VC fund portfolio per VC fund manager per year (i.e., the investment rate per VC manager). The results are consistent with the results for overall portfolio size (e.g., factors that give rise to smaller overall portfolios also give rise to slower investment rates), albeit with a few differences that are detailed herein.

While the results are robust to alternative specifications of included variables in the econometric models, a few results systematically depend on whether the focus is on the full sample of all 214 types of VC funds or the subsample of 104 private independent limited partnerships. The data indicate that limited partnerships provide more value‐added to earlier‐stage entrepreneurial firms, are more constrained in their investment choices (likely because of restrictive covenants), make better use of complementarities and experience from operating more than one VC fund per VC organization, but benefit less from the use of convertible securities. Further, the extent to which returns to scale are diminishing for overall portfolio size (the total number of entrepreneurial firms over the duration of VC fund investment) is less pronounced among the subsample of limited partnerships relative to the full sample of all types of VC funds; however, returns to scale diminish more quickly for the rate of investment (portfolio size per manager per year) among the subsample of private limited partnerships. These systematic differences, which themselves are robust to alternative specifications of the empirics, are most likely attributable to differences in the degree of VC skill, VC fund specialization, governance, and value‐added activities provided to investees. The results suggest many avenues for future research.

This paper is organized as follows.Section IIconsiders the factors that may affect the size of a VC’s portfolio. TheAppendixcomplements the discussion of the theory inSection IIby providing an analysis of nonlinearities in the comparative statics.Section IIIdescribes the data. The empirical estimates are presented inSection IV.Section Vpresents conclusions.

sec.label: II.
sec.title: Comparative Statics and Hypotheses
sec.p: This section builds on previous theoretical research (Kanniainen and Keuschnigg2003,2004) on VC portfolio size by developing a number of proxies for the costs and benefits of having additional entrepreneurial firms in a VC portfolio. The factors that affect VC portfolio size are analyzed at the level of a VCfund, with consideration to VC firms that operate more than one VC fund. I study the total number of entrepreneurial firms in a VC fund portfolio, as well as the number of entrepreneurial firms in the portfolio per VC fund manager. VCs are value‐added active investors that enhance the value of their investee firms (Gompers and Lerner1999b,2001; Keuschnigg2002; Hsu2004). The use of various proxies to account for benefits and costs associated with changing portfolio size is necessary because not all operational data are available from privately run VC firms, and therefore not all pecuniary costs and benefits associated with active value‐added VC investment can be directly measured.

The testable hypotheses are based on the premise that there exists a projected marginal benefit (PMB) and a projected marginal cost (PMC) function associated with the addition of an entrepreneurial firm to a VC portfolio (analogous to Kanniainen and Keuschnigg [2003,2004]). “Projected” refers to expected costs or benefits over the investment horizon. At the point of optimality, a VC will decide to invest when the PMB as a result of the VC’s efforts is greater than or equal to the PMC. The relationship between PMB and PMC is depicted infigure 1. Importantly, note that the theory and empirical tests do not rely on the concavity or convexity of the PMB and PMC functions as depicted infigure 1. The empirics (Sec. IV) directly test for the presence of concavity versus convexity. The nature of the PMB and PMC functions infigure 1is discussed in detail in theAppendix, along with the nonlinearities in the comparative statics. Fig. 1.—
Efficient VC portfolio size and comparative statics

The factors that shift the PMB and PMC curves (seefig. 1) could include (1) the type of VC firm and its number of VC funds, the duration of the VC fund, the number of VC fund managers, and VC fund‐raising; (2) the type of entrepreneurial firm (technology, stage of development, and geographic location); (3) the nature of the financing arrangement (security, deal size, syndication, and staging); and (4) market conditions. As discussed below, in some cases predictions based in the comparative statics largely depend on which effect is emphasized. The fact that the comparative statics do not provide complete guidance renders the empirical tests in the subsequent section both necessary and interesting.

sec.label: A.
sec.title: Venture Capital Fund Characteristics
sec.p: One naturally expects that the PMB of portfolio expansion will be greater, and therefore portfolio size will be larger, among VC funds that have raised more capital, among VC funds that have had a longer time to invest such capital, and among VC funds with a greater number of managers.

Public funds typically have lower productivity because of less human capital, lower salaries and incentive pay, and political pressures to do a greater number of financings in more geographically disparate areas (the political economy literature discussed by Lerner [1999,2002b] suggests that these pressures are powerful). These factors tend to lead public funds to provide much less advice to their investees (Lerner1999). If so, marginal costs of portfolio expansion in terms of providing advice are smaller for public funds (PMC for public funds is below [“to the right of”] PMC for private funds infig. 1). Portfolio size is therefore expected to be greater among public funds (Keuschnigg2003,2004).

Some VC funds are part of VC firms that operate more than one VC fund. On one hand, there are various reasons to indicate that this may have a positive effect on portfolio size. VCs that work for a firm with more than one fund may share resources and effort across funds. In terms offigure 1, the PMC is lower for any given number of entrepreneurial firms in the portfolio. Increasing the size of a VC fund’s portfolio may therefore lead to less of a reduction in the VC’s effort among a VC firm that operates more than one VC fund. There may also be greater networking benefits, complementarities in effort, and benefits to the fund from coinvestment (see also Gompers and Lerner1996) in entrepreneurial firms financed by partner funds (PMB is greater). If so, we would expect that VC funds that are part of VC firms that operate more than one fund will have larger portfolios. However, on the other hand, there are reasons why operating more than one fund may lead to a reduction in portfolio size. For example, VC managers may take time away from operating and actively investing the capital from a first fund to start up a second one (hence, many U.S. limited partnership agreements have covenants to mitigate this problem [Gompers and Lerner1996; Lerner and Schoar2004]; and see Cumming and Johan [forthcoming] for related international evidence). It is necessary to consider the data to see which effect dominates.

sec.label: B.
sec.title: Entrepreneurial Firm Characteristics
sec.p: The composition of a portfolio affects the relative position of the PMB and PMC curves (see Kanniainen and Keuschnigg2003,2004). We may expect earlier‐stage firms and firms in high‐tech industries with intangible assets to have relatively greater PMB and PMC curves (i.e., PMB shifts to the right and PMC shifts to the left). Earlier‐stage firms and firms with intangible assets have more pronounced information asymmetries (Gompers1995) and are therefore associated with higher PMCs. PMBs may also be higher for funds with a focus on earlier‐stage and high‐tech firms because there could be complementarities across firms of similar technologies and stages of development. Many VC funds specialize in particular technologies for this very reason. The net effect of a higher proportion of earlier‐stage and high‐tech investments on portfolio size therefore requires empirical scrutiny.

Entrepreneurial firms that are more geographically disperse relative to the VC fund require extra effort to monitor (see Lerner1995,1999; Gompers and Lerner1999a,1999b,2001; Sorenson and Stuart1999). This increases the marginal costs of portfolio expansion (PMC) and lowers efficient portfolio size (see Kanniainen and Keuschnigg2003,2004; Keuschnigg2003,2004).

sec.label: C.
sec.title: Nature of the Financing Arrangement
sec.p: VC transaction structures are multifaceted, involving security design, staging, and syndication, among other things. Different securities affect the downside protection and upside potential. This in turn affects the VCs’ interest in taking time to actively manage and monitor any particular investment (see Kanniainen and Keuschnigg2003,2004). The VC literature is consistent with the proposition that convertible securities are the optimal form of finance (see, e.g., Sahlman1990; Gompers1997; Bascha and Walz2001a; Casamatta2003; Kaplan and Strömberg2003; Schmidt2003). Since convertibles are a more flexible instrument to allocate incentives to VCs and entrepreneurs, this might strengthen incentives for VC advice and thereby lead them to focus attention to a smaller number of firms to which they can add more value.

We would expect the size of the VC capital contribution to an entrepreneurial firm, relative to the amount of capital provided by the other sources, to be correlated with the VC’s ownership percentage and control rights.1This in turn could affect the costs and benefits of investment in the following ways. On one hand, the greater the VC’s relative stake, the more the benefits to active value‐added investing increase, since a greater proportion of the benefits are retained by the VC. For this reason, portfolio size would be smaller among VCs that invest a greater proportion of the total capital raised by the entrepreneur. On the other hand, if VCs acquire a greater proportion of control rights, this could increase the benefits (both pecuniary and nonpecuniary benefits from having control) and lower the costs (e.g., the expected costs of conflicts of interest between investors and/or with the entrepreneur). Therefore, an increase in the amount invested as a proportion of the total amount of capital raised by the entrepreneur could shift the PMB curve up and the PMC curve down. Therefore, it is also possible that VC funds that invest a greater proportion of the entrepreneur’s total capital will have larger portfolios. In short, theory does not provide unambiguous guidance as to the effect on portfolio size from the relative size of the VC capital contribution. I nevertheless control for the size of capital contributions in the empirics.

VCs typically stage and syndicate their investments. More frequent staging is tantamount to more intensive monitoring (Gompers1995). Relatedly, syndication facilitates risk sharing, monitoring, and screening (Lerner1994). Staging involves intensive monitoring (high PMC) and dilution of VC effort (low PMB). However, staging also provides the VC with the option to wait and not precommit funds, and it provides the VC with the opportunity to renegotiate the terms of the agreement if milestones are not reached (Gompers1995,1997; Kaplan and Strömberg2003). A myriad of theoretical possibilities could arise with the issue of syndication; for example, risk sharing, monitoring, and screening may suggest larger portfolios, but agency problems between syndicated investors may suggest smaller portfolios.2Any predictions on the net impact of these variables on portfolio size would depend on the aspect that is stressed. These limitations of theory are overcome herein by tests with the new data.

The causal relation between these variables is not unambiguous. For any particular investment, the staging decision (and possibly the syndication decision, if syndication comes in at later follow‐on financing rounds) would be made after that of whether to invest. It is also possible that unobserved third factors independently shape these variables. However, the staging and syndication variables herein are measured as the average frequency of staging and syndication for all investees of the VC fund and therefore reflect the degree of monitoring that a VC fund has on a typical investee firm in the portfolio. Factors that affect staging (Gompers1995) and syndication (Lerner1994) aretransaction specific. The staging and syndication variables are averaged across all transactions in a fund in this paper. By including staging and syndication variables as determinants of portfolio size, I am considering the impact of the typical frequency of staging and syndication ontypicalinvestments on themarginaldecision to add an additionalnewentrepreneurial firm to the VC portfolio. The reverse causality would apply only to an analysis of staging and syndication on a transaction‐by‐transaction level (Lerner1994; Gompers1995), whereas my staging and syndication variables are defined asfund averagesand not defined on a transaction‐by‐transaction basis. The same reasoning applies to all choice variables that are transaction specific: the average of all transaction‐specific variables is used to asses the impact on overall portfolio size, and therefore endogeneity is not a significant concern (see also n. 9 below).

fn.p: Gompers (1997) and Kaplan and Strömberg (2003) find that control rights and cash flow rights are independently allocated. Nevertheless, this is not inconsistent with a prediction that larger capital commitments from an investor give rise to more investor bargaining power to demand more scope for control (see, e.g., Noe and Rebello1996; Cumming2002).

Jaaskelainen, Maula, and Seppa (forthcoming) provide some evidence of a positive relation between portfolio size and syndication using correlation coefficients and U.S. data; however, they do not provide any tests of the determinants of portfolio size. They focus on the impact of portfolio size on exit outcomes. Manigart et al. (2002) provide some evidence of a negative relation between portfolio size and syndication using correlation coefficients and European data; however, they do not provide any formal tests of the determinants of portfolio size.

sec.label: D.
sec.title: Market Conditions
sec.p: Lerner (2002a) (see also Kortum and Lerner2000) finds that the impact of VC on innovation is approximately 15% lower during boom periods than during normal periods, and this difference is strongly statistically significant. Lerner’s empirical work thus points to an important trade‐off between portfolio size and VC involvement (advice) and points to variations over the business cycle (for supportive theoretical work on this topic, see Kanniainen and Keuschnigg [2003,2004] and Keuschnigg [2003,2004]). I therefore control for market conditions using Morgan Stanley Capital International (MSCI) real returns3over the period from the date of the first VC fund investment to the date of the last VC fund investment. We expect that, for example, portfolios formed over the 1991–93 period will be smaller than portfolios formed over the period 1997–99 because returns were greater in the later period.

The variables described above and used in the empirical tests below are summarized intable 1. As mentioned, nonlinearities are important in the comparative statics, and these nonlinearities are explained in theAppendix. Before proceeding with the empirical tests inSection IV, I first describe the data inSection III. Table 1
Definitions of Variables
Variable Name Variable Description
Venture capital fund characteristics:
Portfolio size No. of entrepreneurial firms in the VC portfolio
Average no. of portfolio firms/no. of VC managers No. of entrepreneurial firms in the VC portfolio/no. of VC fund managers
Average no. of portfolio firms/no. of VC managers/no. of years No. of entrepreneurial firms in the VC portfolio/no. of VC fund managers/investment period duration period (measured in years, with accuracy to quarters) (i.e., this variable measures the investment rate/manager)
Corporate VC Dummy variable that is equal to one if the VC fund is a corporate fund
Government VC Dummy variable that is equal to one if the VC fund is a Canadian government fund
LSVCC Dummy variable that is equal to one if the VC fund is a Canadian labor‐sponsored venture capital fund
Private independent VC Dummy variable that is equal to one if the VC fund is a limited partnership fund
Two or more VC funds in the VC firm Dummy variable equal to one if the VC fund is part of a VC firm that operates two or more VC funds
VC funds raised (drawdowns) Amount of funds raised by the VC fund, proxied by the total drawdowns by the fund
No. of years fund investments tracked by CVCA No. of years for which the VC fund is tracked by the Canadian Venture Capital Association (Macdonald & Associates) in the database. This variable is used to exclude only the funds in the data that have been tracked for fewer than two years
Investment duration period (quarters) Duration of time (measured in quarters of years) over which the VC fund invested in entrepreneurial firms; could be less than two years or even one year if all fund investments occurred toward the end of one year and the beginning of the next year
No. of VC fund managers No. of VC fund managers employed by the fund
Entrepreneurial firm characteristics:
Early stage Proportion of investees in the start‐up and expansion stage of development at the time of first VC investment
Life sciences Proportion of investees in life sciences industries
Other high‐tech Proportion of investees in technology industries other than life sciences
Entrepreneur/VC different provinces Proportion of investees resident in provinces in which the VC fund does not have an office
Financing transaction characteristics:
Staging frequency Proportion of staged investments
Syndication frequency Proportion of syndicated investments
VC investments/entrepreneurial capital Amount of VC capital provided to entrepreneur/total capital raised by the entrepreneurial firm at the time of VC investment
Convertible securities Proportion of investments with the use of convertible debt and/or convertible preferred equity
Market conditions:
MSCI return Morgan Stanley Capital International index real return from the date (year and quarter) of the VC fund first investment to date of last investment
Returns to scale:
λ Degree of curvature of the output function, based on the Box‐Cox transformation

fn.p: I use industry rates of return, and not rates of return from the VC funds themselves, since these returns are arguably endogenous (i.e., portfolio size determines individual fund VC rates of return and not vice versa; see, e.g., Jaaskelainen et al. [forthcoming]). I did consider annualized vs. total MSCI rates of return as well as other industry rates of return (e.g., U.S. VC rates of return, as reported in Lerner [2002a]), but the qualitative conclusions were not materially different. I report the MSCI rates of return because these returns are widely regarded as a measure of market sentiment and arguably are the most reliable measure of returns in the Canadian market.

sec.label: A.
sec.title: Description of the Data
sec.p: The data were obtained from a large sample of VC financing transactions over the years 1991–2000 from Macdonald & Associates (http://www.canadavc.com) for the Canadian Venture Capital Association. Canadian data are used primarily because the CVCA has assembled a unique VC database with details that are not available from VC associations in the United States or other countries around the world. Not all the funds in the Macdonald & Associates database are used herein. In order to mitigate the possibility of missing investments, I excluded from the data funds that were tracked by Macdonald & Associates for fewer than two years.4In net, 214 funds were included: 104 private independent limited partnership venture funds, 18 corporate funds, 15 government funds, 29 labor‐sponsored VC corporations (LSVCCs), and 48 institutional funds. The results are quite robust to the inclusion/exclusion of the full set of 214 funds, but there are notable differences between the full sample of all 214 funds and the subsample of 104 limited partnerships; these differences are most likely attributable to fund structures, as explained below.

Note that I distinguish between the duration from first to last investment and the numbers of years the fund’s investments were tracked by Macdonald & Associates. The number of years the fund was tracked is used only to define the sample, as discussed immediately above. The period of investment duration (time from the quarter of the first investment to the quarter of the last investment) is used hereafter in the empirics. Nine of the funds in the sample had investment durations of less than one year (i.e., these nine funds were tracked for at least two full years but made investments toward the latter part of the first year and earlier part of the second year only).

Each type of VC fund in Canada has been discussed elsewhere (e.g., Macdonald1992; MacIntosh1994; Halpern1997). Briefly, private independent limited partnerships are analogous to those in the United States (Gompers and Lerner1996,1999b), as are corporate funds (Gompers and Lerner1999a,1999b). Government funds are direct investment programs financed by the government and run by professional VC managers. LSVCCs are mutual funds with tax incentives for individual investors to contribute capital, and this capital is reinvested in entrepreneurial firms. LSVCC governance mechanisms are based in statute, unlike limited partnership covenants (as studied in seminal work by Gompers and Lerner [1996,1999b]).

Summary statistics for the duration of the fund, fund‐raising, the average amounts invested, and the average total deal sizes (total capital raised by the entrepreneurial firm) are provided intable 2. Corporate VCs and private independent limited partnerships have smaller portfolios than LSVCCs and government VCs in the sample (see panel A oftable 2). Most all funds in Canada invest in earlier stages (start‐up and expansion stages), and most invest in high‐tech industries. In the data employed herein, the information on fund‐raising was incomplete. Fund‐raising is therefore proxied by fund drawdowns (i.e., amounts invested) from capital commitments. This proxy is suitable because I also account for the number of years in which the fund has been investing capital in entrepreneurial firms, which gives an indication of the proportion of total capital raised that has been invested by the VC fund.5On average, LSVCCs have raised the most capital (because of favorable tax treatment), whereas limited partnerships have raised significantly less capital. Lerner (1994), Gompers (1995), and Gompers and Lerner (1999b,2001) analyze the staging and syndication decision in terms of agency problems, monitoring, and risk sharing. In this data set, as a percentage of all investments (first and later financing rounds), roughly half (47% for government VCs, 54% for private independent VCs, and 56% for corporate VCs) were staged. Corporate VCs syndicated their investments more frequently (62% of their total investments), and government VCs syndicated least frequently (46%). Relatedly, institutional investors, on average, provided the most capital as a fraction of the total entrepreneurial capital at the time of investment (63%), whereas private independent limited partners provided the smallest proportion of entrepreneurial capital (48%) among the funds in the sample. Although the details in the data do not enable an analysis of urban versus rural investments, I nevertheless control for entrepreneurial firm location relative to the investor with the use of a variable that measures the frequency of intra‐ versus interprovincial investment. On average, more than 80% of investments were intraprovincial (in which the investor and investee resided in the same province).

LSVCCs used convertible securities (convertible debt and/or convertible preferred equity) most frequently (27% of investments); government and institutional VCs used convertibles least frequently (20%).6Variables for other securities are not considered in the empirics below to mitigate problems associated with collinearity. As discussed inSection II.C , I focus on the securities that are regarded as optimal in VC finance: convertible securities.

fn.p: This was suggested by Macdonald & Associates; seehttp://www.canadaa.com. A prior version of the paper (on file with the author) excluded funds that invested in 1991, 1999, and 2000 (a total of 79 funds). See also n. 15 below.

It is noteworthy, however, that there may still exist some “unobserved” (pre‐1991 and post‐2000) investments in the data. To account for this problem in the econometric estimates inSec. IVbelow, a heteroscedastic specification is used with duration as the weighting variable.

It is possible that other factors could affect drawdowns independent of fund‐raising. The data in this paper do not enable full consideration of this issue. Further research is warranted. See also Ljungqvist and Richardson (2003) and Cumming, Fleming, and Suchard (2005) on fund‐raising vs. drawdowns.

The use of a variety of forms of finance for Canadian entrepreneurial firms is not due to the definition of venture capital (by type of VC fund or by type of entrepreneurial firm); see Cumming (2005a,2005b,2006). See Bascha and Walz (2001b), Cumming (2002), and Schwienbacher (2002) for similar evidence from independent samples derived from the population of European VC funds; see Lerner and Schoar (2005) for similar evidence from developing countries. In the United States, by contrast, convertible preferred equity is most common in venture capital (Gompers1997; Kaplan and Strömberg2003). One explanation for this difference across countries is that there is a unique tax bias in favor of convertible preferred equity in the United States (Gilson and Schizer2003).

sec.p:

The cutoff points for the comparison tests were somewhat arbitrarily chosen to be close to the means of the variables (as indicated intable 2); additional comparison tests are available on request. The comparison tests generally indicate that larger overall portfolios are observed among the corporate funds, government funds, and LSVCCs (relative to limited partnerships), as well as among VC firms with two or more funds, VC funds that have capital of more than real 2000 Can$50,000,000, funds that have been investing for at least four years, funds with more than seven managers, funds with less than 50% of the investments in life science or other types of high‐tech firms, funds that invest more frequently in entrepreneurs resident in the same province, and funds that stage more but syndicate less frequently. Some differences in overall portfolio size are observed between the full sample of 214 funds and the subsample of 104 limited partnerships. Among the full sample, VCs that invest a greater proportion relative to the entrepreneurs’ other sources of capital have larger portfolios but smaller portfolios among the limited partnerships. Funds that invest in life science industries and use convertible securities more frequently among the full sample of 214 funds have smaller portfolios, but theses differences of means are not statistically significant among the 104 limited partnerships. Overall portfolio size seems invariant to MSCI returns over the investment period among the full sample of funds, but portfolio size is smaller among funds that invested in boom periods among the subsample of limited partnerships.

The comparisons of means tests for portfolio size per manager per year (investment rates per manager) yield similar results, with the following exceptions. First, investment rates are invariant among VC firms with and without more than one VC fund, fund‐raising, and entrepreneur industry (where these factors were significant for overall portfolio size). Second, investment rates are higher when MSCI returns are higher among the full sample of all 214 funds (but not among the limited partnerships, and different results are also observed in regard to overall portfolio size in the difference of means tests). Finally, it is noteworthy that investment rates are higher among government VCs and LSVCCs, but there is no difference in investment rates among corporate VCs and limited partnerships (despite the finding that corporate funds have larger overall portfolios, as mentioned above).7

Tables4and5provide correlation matrices, and the correlations are generally consistent with the comparison tests intable 3. Tables3,4, and5provide a useful starting point for analyzing the data. Additional empirical tests in a multivariate context are obviously warranted. Portfolio size is not uniquely attributable to any single variable. Moreover, the theory described in theAppendixpredicts a nonlinear relation between portfolio size and the enumerated factors discussed above, and this nonlinear relation is best tested in a multivariate setting. fn.p: In regard to investment duration, one may speculate that investment rates slow over the life of a fund. For the number of managers, one could argue that investment rates slow if it is inefficient for a greater number of VC managers to be working together. In the regression specifications in panel B of tables6and7below, note that I do not include the number of managers and investment duration as right‐hand‐side variables. When these variables are included, they tend to be negative and significant (at around the 10% level of significance), without significantly affecting the other included right‐hand‐side variables. The main reason for their exclusion is that these variables would appear on both the right‐ and left‐hand sides of the regression equations, which is obviously undesirable.

sec.label: A.
sec.title: Empirical Methods
sec.p:
Two different dependent variables are considered: (1) the total number of entrepreneurial firms in the portfolio (panel A in tables6and7) and (2) the total number of entrepreneurial firms/the number of managers/the time period of investment (panel B in tables6and7). The first considers overall portfolio size, and the second considers the investment rate. I employ similar strategies for estimating both variables and compare the results. The data are segregated for the subsample of private independent funds (table 7), as well as pooled with all firm types together (table 6). (Other subsamples are not considered because of the comparative dearth of observations.) The advantage of segregating the data is that differences may exist across types of VC firms. In the pooled sample, dummy variables for the type of VC firm are employed (a dummy for “other institutional” types is suppressed to avoid collinearity). Table 6

Two different regression models are presented in the tables: a linear model and Box‐Cox transformations of the right‐hand‐side variables with a heteroscedastic specification. The Box‐Cox specification is consistent with the theory explained in theAppendix. Right‐hand‐side variables include all the entrepreneurial firm and transaction characteristics discussed inSection II. Each variable is defined as the proportion of the total VC fund portfolio with the particular characteristic. For example, the variable “life sciences” is the proportion of all investments in a VC fund’s portfolio that were in life science (biotechnology and medical) firms. Dummy variables are included for the type of VC firm in the full‐sample estimates. Transformations to independent variables (other than the dummy variables) are presented to capture nonlinearities in the relationship between portfolio size and the factors described inSection II. The intuition underlying the possible existence of nonlinearities was explained inSection II.D . The variables used in the empirical analysis are summarized intable 1.

The linear ordinary least squares (OLS) model is presented for comparison (model 2); models 1 and 3–5 involve Box‐Cox estimations, with consideration to heteroscedasticity. Significant correlations are observed among some of the variables, particularly the entrepreneurial firm and transaction‐specific variables; as such, regressions are provided with alternative right‐hand‐side variables to show robustness.

The likelihood dominance criterion and the various information criterion statistics were supportive of the complete set of explanatory variables; therefore, the discussion herein focuses on the complete set of explanatory variables in the heteroscedastic Box‐Cox specification (model 1).9The other models are provided in the tables for comparison. The estimates are very similar across the six models in tables6and7, and differences in results are explained below alongside the discussion of statistical and economic significance.10

fn.p: The heteroscedastic specification is not relevant in the panel B estimates in tables6and7that explain the rate of investment because each investment per year is observed in each year in which the funds exist in the data; see also n. 7.

As discussed, some of the right‐hand‐side variables are choice variables, such as staging and syndication. The decision to add another entrepreneurial firm to the portfolio depends on the prior structure of the portfolio, including the proportion of investments that were staged and syndicated, the proportion of firms that are financed with convertible securities, etc. Portfolio size is not uniquely determined at the outset prior to knowing all investment opportunities, each entrepreneurial firm’s required capital, the needs associated with advice and/or monitoring for each firm, etc. Financing structure, including staging, syndication, and contracting, depends on entrepreneurial firm‐specific factors (Lerner1994; Gompers1995,1997; Gompers and Lerner1999b). Marginal effects on the decision to expand portfolio size depend on prior investment decisions, among other things. Note that I also considered specification tests (e.g., Durbin‐Wu‐Hausman tests; Davidson and MacKinnon [1993]) for endogeneity, etc., which did not indicate a reason to be concerned with endogeneity, and numerous alternative specification tests suggested that these variables should be included.

There is a statistical modeling issue with making exact predictions regarding economic significance with the Box‐Cox model. In particular, in contrast to the linear regression model 2, the error disturbance term does not drop out of the expectation in a Box‐Cox model. Abrevaya (2000) suggests various ways to account for the error term by introducing new distributional assumptions. Greene (1997), on the other hand, advocates ignoring the error term (which of course makes the most sense when the residuals are small). Given the unusually high adjustedR 2for the Box‐Cox regressions in tables6and7(for model 1, equal to 0.89 in panel A oftable 6and 0.98 in panel A oftable 7), I adopt the approach advocated by Greene in the presentation of the marginal effects in tables6and7for model 1. (Regardless, Abrevaya's alternative approach generally yields similar results for economic significance under most distributional assumptions.)

sec.label: B.
sec.title: Empirical Results
sec.p: For reasons indicated immediately above, unless otherwise indicated, I focus the discussion on model 1 in each of the tables and panels. The other models are presented to indicate robustness. Panel A oftable 6analyzes the overall portfolio sizes as measured by the total number of entrepreneurial firms. The dummy variables for private independent limited partnership VCs and corporate VCs indicate that these funds have smaller portfolios (the coefficients are negative and significant at the 1% level). (Recall that a dummy for other institutional investors was suppressed to avoid perfect collinearity.) This was an expected result given that corporate and private independent VCs are reputed to be the most value‐added active investors (seeSec. II.A ). The corporate and private funds have, on average, approximately five and 11 fewer entrepreneurial firms in their portfolios, respectively, other things being equal across funds. Model 1 indicates that the tax‐subsidized LSVCC and government VC coefficients are positive but statistically insignificant, whereas models 3–6 indicate positive and significant coefficients (these public funds have approximately five more entrepreneurial firms in their portfolios, other things being equal).

Panel B oftable 6analyzes the rate of investment (number of entrepreneurial firms per manager per year). In contrast to overall portfolio sizes, significant differences in rates of portfolio size expansion are not observed across the different types of funds in the full sample. Nevertheless, as discussed below, we do observe differences in the determinants of the rates of investment between the full sample (table 6, panel B) and the subsample of limited partnerships (table 7, panel B).

In the full‐sample estimates (table 6, panel A), VC funds that belong to VC firms with two or more VC funds (Sec. II.A ) have 14 fewer entrepreneurial firms in their portfolio. In the subsample of private independent funds (table 7, panel A), VC organizations with more than one fund also have smaller portfolios (but the marginal effect is much smaller, at approximately 0.2 fewer entrepreneurial firms in their portfolio depending on the specification).11The rates of investment are not materially different for VC firms with two or more funds in the full sample (table 6, panel B), but are slower among the subsample of limited partnerships (table 7, panel B), whereby there is approximately 0.5 fewer entrepreneurial firm in a portfolio per VC manager per year. There are two potential interpretations of these results. On the one hand, one may view these results as suggestive of agency problems in the allocation of VC effort in the establishment of the second and subsequent funds in the same VC firm (see Gompers and Lerner1996). That is, VC managers appear to be investing less and possibly spending more time on fund‐raising efforts when setting up multiple funds. The benefits of VC managerial experience value‐added, networking, and complementarities, among other things (see Sahlman1990; Gompers and Lerner1999b,2001) appear to mitigate the agency effect for the subsample of limited partnerships. The results also suggest that, consistent with Gompers and Lerner (1996), private independent limited partnerships have stronger governance mechanisms pertaining to fund‐raising and the establishment of new venture funds. On the other hand, one may view these results as indicating a greater degree of skill among VC managers in firms with more than one fund, and therefore these funds are better off by financing less and advising more. It would be fruitful to investigate this issue further in follow‐up work to see how exactly a VC’s time is allocated between fund‐raising and advising. The fact that private independent funds are widely regarded as providing more advice relative to other fund types, together with the fact that private independent funds typically have strong governance mechanisms in setting up follow‐on funds, suggests that the second interpretation is more plausible: VC firms with two or more funds have VCs that spend more time advising than financing.

As expected (seeSec. II.A ), the multivariate results in tables6and7(panel A) also indicate that more fund‐raising (proxied by total drawdowns) leads to larger portfolios. Raising an additional $10,000,000 in capital would increase portfolio size by two entrepreneurial firms for the full sample of all fund types (table 6, panel A) but only one extra entrepreneurial firm in the portfolio of a private independent limited partnership (table 7, panel A). Rates of investment are unaffected by fund‐raising (as indicated in the panel B estimates, with the exception of the OLS model).12

In panel A oftable 7, the duration coefficient is positive and significant, which was expected (Sec. II.A ); other things being equal, an extra year of investing, on average, leads to slightly more than one new entrepreneurial firm in the portfolio. However, the coefficient for the duration variable is either negative and significant or insignificant intable 6, depending on the specification in models 1–5. It is likely that the presence of LSVCCs in the data used fortable 6distorts the duration effect intable 6. LSVCCs do not have a finite horizon (unlike limited partnerships) and face a large number of statutory restrictive covenants that may distort the duration variable. Similar distortions to the duration coefficient may arise from the presence of government funds in the full sample intable 6(see MacIntosh1994; Halpern1997; Lerner1999,2002b).13

The evidence also indicates that entrepreneurial firm characteristics affect portfolio size. VCs that invest in a greater proportion of early‐stage entrepreneurial firms have larger portfolios in the full sample of all types of VCs (table 6, panel A; an increase of 10% in the proportion of start‐ups gives rise to approximately one more entrepreneurial firm in the portfolio), but this effect is insignificant in the subsample of limited partnerships (table 7, panel A). Investment rates are not materially different for early‐stage entrepreneurs among all types of funds (table 6, panel B) but are higher among the subsample of limited partnerships (table 7, panel B) such that an increase of 10% in the proportion of early‐stage investments increases portfolio size by 0.06 firm per manager per year. These results are suggestive of scale economies through specialization in early development stages.

The life science, other high‐tech, and early‐stage variables are not reported together because of collinearity problems. For reasons of succinctness, I do not report the marginal effects in the tables for the other specifications with the tech variables, but discuss these marginal effects below. The evidence in panel A oftable 7indicates that funds with a 10% greater proportion of life science (biotechnology and health) investees tend to have larger portfolios by approximately 0.1 entrepreneurial firm (but this effect is insignificant for rates of investment in panel B oftable 7and insignificant in the full sample in panels A and B oftable 6). Funds with other types of high‐tech firms are typically associated with smaller portfolios and slower rates of investment (tables6and7, panels A and B). Generally, the evidence indicates that increasing the proportion of other high‐tech firms in the portfolio across all fund types (table 6, Panel A, models 3 and 5) by 10% would reduce the portfolio size by one entrepreneurial firm; whereas increasing the proportion of other high‐tech firms in the subsample of private independent funds (table 7, panel A, models 3 and 5) would reduce portfolio size by 0.05 entrepreneurial firm. There is some evidence that rates of investment are also slower among tech firms (tables6and7, panel B, model 3) such that a 10% increase in tech investments slows the rate of portfolio expansion by 0.09 entrepreneurial firm per year per manager among all types of funds and by 0.04 entrepreneurial firm per year per manager among limited partnership funds. Differences between the effect of life science investments and other high‐tech investments could be attributable to the time it takes to bring an investment to fruition or the degree to which complementarities may exist among different entrepreneurial firms in the VC portfolio (seeSec. II.B ). The data suggest that life science investments take longer between the first investment date and exit date (possibly because of delays in obtaining patent approval etc.), which would be associated with an increase in portfolio size since the VC’s effort can be spread across a greater number of firms at different periods of time. The data are also consistent with the idea that complementarities across entrepreneurial firms are greater among funds with a focus on firms in the life science industries.

There is fairly strong evidence that geographic proximity affects overall portfolio size as well as the rate of portfolio expansion. A 10% increase in extraprovincial investment lowers portfolio size by approximately two entrepreneurial firms among all types of funds (table 6, panel A) and by 0.3 entrepreneurial firm among the subsample of limited partnerships (table 7, panel A). Likewise, the rate of investment is lower among funds that invest more frequently in out‐of‐province entrepreneurs: a 10% increase in extraprovincial investments decreases the rate of investment by 0.07 entrepreneurial firm per VC per year (this effect is significant in panel B oftable 7in all specifications, but significant only at the 10% level in model 5 of panel B oftable 6). The evidence thus indicates that geographic distance requires extra monitoring, which increases PMC and therefore lowers portfolio size.

The coefficient for amount invested per investee relative to the total amount of capital raised by the entrepreneurial firm is negative and significant. A 10% increase, on average, gives rise to two fewer firms in the portfolio among all VC fund types (table 6, panel A) and 0.6 fewer firm in a private independent VC portfolio (table 7, panel A). Similarly, a 10% increase gives rise to 0.1 fewer firm per manager per year among the full sample of funds (table 6, panel B; but this effect is insignificant among the subsample of limited partnerships intable 7, panel B). Overall, this evidence is generally consistent with the prediction that VCs obtain a greater ownership interest in entrepreneurial firms since they provide more capital relative to the total amount of entrepreneurial capital (Sec. II.C ). As such, a VC’s incentive to add value to a small number of firms is high because the opportunity cost of portfolio expansion is high and the VC retains a larger proportion of the benefits.

The convertible securities coefficient is negative and significant in the full sample of all 214 funds. A 10% increase in the use of convertible securities gives rise to a smaller portfolio by 1.2 entrepreneurial firms when all funds are considered together (table 6, panel A). Because convertible securities are widely regarded as optimal in VC finance (Sahlman1990; Gompers1997; Kaplan and Strömberg2003), we had expected a significant and negative coefficient (there is an incentive to advise more and finance fewer firms; seeSec. II.C ). Although we do find support for this conjecture in the sample of all 214 VC funds intable 6, the coefficient for convertible securities is positive and significant among the subsample of 104 limited partnership funds only in panel A oftable 7(a 10% increase in the use of convertible securities increases portfolio size by approximately 0.2 entrepreneurial firm among private independent funds). The data thus indicate that there are benefits to the use of convertibles among most VC funds (in terms of providing incentives to focus efforts on advising more and financing less), but not the limited partnership funds. Although there has been little research on VC structure in relation to VC characteristics (such as different types of limited partnership agreements and restrictive covenants, the structure of corporate and government funds, etc.), this evidence suggests that there are important differences worthy of further study. It is further noteworthy that the use of convertibles does not affect the rate of portfolio expansion in this data set (tables6and7, panel B).

On the basis of Lerner (2002a), I had expected (seeSec. II.D ) VCs to invest more and finance less in boom economic periods. There is some evidence consistent with this prediction. The overall total size of VC portfolios among all fund types (table 6, panel A) is generally invariant to the MSCI returns over the period in which the portfolio was formed (with the exception of model 1, but this evidence is not robust), but there is evidence of a positive effect among some of the specifications for the subsample of limited partnerships (models 3, 5, and 6 in panel A oftable 7). In particular, for limited partnerships a 10% increase in MSCI returns gives rise to greater portfolio sizes by approximately 0.2 entrepreneurial firm. There is further evidence that higher MSCI returns over the investment period increase the rate of portfolio expansion among all fund types (table 6, panel B, models 1–6): a 10% increase in MSCI returns increases portfolio size per manager per year by approximately 0.2 entrepreneurial firm (but this effect is not significant among thetable 7, panel B, results for limited partnerships). The partial nonrobustness of the results is likely attributable to the impreciseness associated with a single market return variable to measure expectations. I considered alternative measures (e.g., small cap index returns) but did not find a better fit, and alternative measures for returns are not simultaneously included to avoid collinearity.14Overall, despite the fact that these results are not quite as robust as most of the other effects, one may infer from the evidence that there exists a positive connection between portfolio sizes and market returns. Consistent with Kortum and Lerner’s (2000) and Lerner’s (2002a) evidence that VCs contribute less to innovation in boom periods (for a supportive theory, see also Kanniainen and Keuschnigg [2004]), in boom periods VCs also finance more but advise less.

fn.p: It is worthwhile reconciling this result with the comparison tests in tables4and5. The comparison tests, which indicate larger portfolios for two or more VC funds per VC firm, are attributable to a greater number of VC managers and larger values for fund‐raising (drawdowns) among VC firms with two or more VC funds. Portfolio size per manager and portfolio size per amount of fund‐raising (drawdowns) are smaller among funds with two or more VC funds per VC firm relative to funds with only one VC fund per VC firm. The effects of the number of managers and fund‐raising (drawdowns) are picked up in the regressions.

To match the definition of the dependent variable on the estimates of rates of investment in panel B, I scaled the fund‐raising (drawdowns) variable by dividing it by the number of managers and the number of years. Failure to do this would lead to estimates of very large increasing returns to scale (i.e., the econometric specification would be looking at lots of capital per manager to invest each year compared to very low investment rates). Alternative specifications are available on request.

The duration coefficient intable 6may also be explained by the pronounced amount of uninvested capital on behalf of funds without a finite termination date (particularly LSVCCs and government funds). I noted above (seeSec. II.A ) that the fund‐raising (proxied by drawdowns) and duration variables go hand‐in‐hand: over a longer period, a greater proportion of the fund's capital will be invested, particularly as the fund termination date looms. There is no fund termination date for LSVCCs and government funds. Also, note that collinearity was a problem with the duration variable intable 6, which gave rise to either negative and significant or insignificant coefficients depending on the specification. Nevertheless, note that no specification yielded estimates of a positive relation between duration and portfolio size.

See also n. 3. Note that the duration and returns variables are somewhat correlated, but the inclusion or exclusion of either of these variables does not materially affect the significance of these results. Alternative specifications are available on request.

A prior version of this paper studied funds that had invested over the 1992–98 period (see nn. 12 and 13), whereas the current paper studies funds that invested over the 1991–2000 period (as discussed inSec. III, the current paper excludes funds that had invested for only one year from the CVCA data). There were fewer funds in the prior paper (79) and therefore fewer degrees of freedom in the econometric tests, which gave rise to less robust results in estimating the returns to scale. With the more complete sample of funds used intable 6(214 funds) andtable 7(104 funds), the results are very robust to alternative specifications. It is further noteworthy that when the dependent variable is expressed as the number of investors per VC manager, it is possible for λ to be greater than one without redefining some of the right‐hand‐side variables (for reasons related to the discussion in n. 12).

Note, however, that the economic effects of the various explanatory factors on portfolio size are generally larger intable 6for all funds considered in unison, relative to the subsample of private independent limited partnerships intable 7(as discussed throughout subsectionB). One may infer that the main reason for the smaller coefficients among the private limited partnerships intable 7is that the private funds themselves are generally smaller (i.e., they employ fewer VC managers and have less capital under management etc.; seetable 2) and face more onerous restrictive covenants, which makes it relatively more difficult to change investment strategies (cf. Gompers and Lerner1996; Lerner and Schoar2004).

sec.label: C.
sec.title: Further Robustness Checks, Limitations, and Alternative Explanations
sec.p: This paper provides a first look at the empirical determinants of VC portfolio size. A broad array of factors were considered within three primary categories: VC fund characteristics, entrepreneurial firm characteristics, the structure of the financing transactions, and market conditions.

A variety of robustness checks were provided in subsectionB. There are additional issues of robustness not provided in the tables (for reasons of conciseness; however, these robustness checks are available on request from the author). Some examples are mentioned here. First, the degree of curvature in the Box‐Cox transformation may be different for different variables. Second, we may exclude different funds from the complete sample intable 6, such as the LSVCCs. Third, we may exclude funds from the sample on the basis of the structure of their transactions and/or the types of entrepreneurial firms that they finance. In general, to the extent that we are able to make inferences with the data, these various alternative specifications did not materially affect the results and conclusions arising from the data presented above.

There are additional robustness checks that I would have liked to have been able to consider, but they were not feasible with the data. For example, I do not have accurate data that distinguish the number of people who work in the capacity of the fund manager, fund advisor, fund analyst, fund support staff, and fund consultants for each of the funds. I do know (on the basis of anecdotal evidence) that at least some of the funds in Canada have staff that work in these different roles. But despite this data limitation, note that fund size based on staff in different capacities is significantly positively correlated with the number of VC fund managers and capital under management (again, on the basis of anecdotal evidence), which are both accounted for in the data and tests (among other things). As such, I do not believe that these additional details would materially affect the inferences that can be drawn from the available data.

There are further details that could be useful in the empirical analysis of VC portfolio size. For example, in this data set we do not know the relative importance of financial, administrative, marketing, strategic, and so forth advice provided by each fund to its entrepreneurial investees, as well as the number of days per month spent with the investees. We also do not know the valuations assigned to the different entrepreneurial firms in the portfolios (which may be positively correlated with fund‐raising; see Gompers and Lerner [2000]). In addition, we do not know the extent to which different VC funds use different covenants. Again, these are limitations in detail that are difficult (or impossible) to overcome in the collection of confidential private VC data. I nevertheless do stress that I considered robustness across a wide variety of types of venture funds (limited partnerships, corporate VCs, government VCs, etc.). Also, despite the limitations, this is the first data set for which it is possible to test the determinants of VC portfolio size, and I have considered a broad array of factors for VC fund and entrepreneurial firm characteristics, the nature of the financing transactions, and market conditions.

sec.label: V.
sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The empirical evidence supports the theoretical proposition that there is a trade‐off between VC assistance to entrepreneurial firms in the VC’s portfolio and the size of the portfolio (Kanniainen and Keuschnigg2003,2004). Consistent with recent developments in the banking literature (Hughes et al.2001), portfolio size in VC is affected by risk taking, capital structure, and a number of other factors related to agency costs, costs of investing and monitoring, and the potential for value maximization. The data introduced in this paper enable a first look at the empirical determinants of VC portfolio size and whether there are diminishing returns to scale in the number of entrepreneurial firm investees in a VC fund portfolio.

The nature of value‐added active VC investing requires the use of pecuniary measures of investment costs as well as proxies for the nonpecuniary costs and benefits associated with changes in portfolio size. The data indicate four main categories of significant factors that affect portfolio size: (1) characteristics of the VC fund, (2) characteristics of the entrepreneurial firms, (3) characteristics of the financing arrangements, and (4) market conditions. First, fund‐raising and the number of funds operated by the VC firm have a significantly positive impact on VC portfolio size. Government‐sponsored VC funds have larger portfolios, and corporate and private independent limited partnerships have smaller portfolios. VC funds with more VC managers also have larger portfolios. Second, portfolio size is affected by the composition of the portfolio in terms of high‐tech and early‐stage investments. Third, portfolio size is significantly affected by the nature of the financing arrangements, including capital structure, staging, syndication, and the amount of VC capital invested in the entrepreneurial firm relative to the capital provided by other investors. Fourth, sizes of portfolios are larger when they are formed during boom periods.

Interestingly, both the theory and evidence indicate the existence of a nonlinear relation in these factors that determine portfolio size. The evidence indicates that returns to scale are diminishing in the number of investee firms in VC fund portfolios, and there are differences in the degree of nonlinearities depending on the type of VC fund.

The data indicated a few effects that were different among the subsample of 104 limited partnerships relative to the full sample of all 214 funds. Most notably, the data suggest that limited partnerships provide more value‐added to earlier‐stage entrepreneurial firms, are more constrained in their investment choices (likely because of restrictive covenants), make better use of complementarities and experience from operating more than one VC fund per VC organization, but benefit less from the use of convertible securities. Limited partnerships also have less pronounced diminishing returns to scale for overall portfolio size but more pronounced diminishing returns to scale for the rate of portfolio expansion (portfolio size per manager per investment years). The heterogeneity across different VC fund types could provide a fruitful avenue for future theoretical and empirical research on many issues in venture finance, such as capital structure, VC value‐added, rates of innovation among venture‐backed companies, and the returns to venture capital investment. It would also be worthwhile to explore international differences in returns to scale and the determinants of VC portfolio size among VC funds across countries.

app.label: Appendix
app.p: This appendix discusses the intuition underlying the nonlinearities in the factors that affect efficient VC fund portfolio size. Consider the shape of the PMB and PMC curves (fig. 1). The PMB curve may slope upward over a small number of portfolio firms if, for example, there exist complementarities across different entrepreneurial firms in a portfolio.17These benefits, however, do not exist over all ranges of portfolio expansion. That the PMB function will eventually slope downward is based on multitask principal agent theory (Holmström and Milgrom1991) and the law of diminishing returns (see, e.g., Gwartney and Stroup1997). For a given level of VC fund resources (including the number of VC managers), the value‐added provided to all the entrepreneurial firms in the portfolio decreases as portfolio size increases. Further, multitask principal agency theory and the traditional microeconomic principle of diminishing marginal productivity (Gwartney and Stroup1997) suggest a concave PMB function. The addition of each investee firm to a VC portfolio will decrease the marginal value of active VC investment at an increasing rate as the number of portfolio firms increases.18As with PMB, the slope and convex shape of the PMC function also follow from basic microeconomic cost function theory. The marginal cost of financing an additional firm may decrease for a small number of investee firms in a VC portfolio in which similar value‐added activities overlap across investees. Marginal costs, however, do not fall to zero; rather, marginal costs fall at a decreasing rate and eventually increase. Given a fixed level of resources in a VC fund, for every additional entrepreneurial firm added to a VC fund portfolio, there are not only direct costs of financing and assisting the firm but also opportunity costs of reduced assistance to the other firms in the portfolio.19Consistent with the law of diminishing returns, the marginal costs of increasing portfolio size will in fact increase at an increasing rate as the portfolio expands; therefore, we may expect the PMC curve to be convex.

If PMB is concave and PMC is convex, as depicted infigure 1, then the relations between the variables that shift the PMC and PMB function and portfolio size will be concave.20A percentage increase in the “shift” variables (as described throughoutSec. II) will have a smaller effect on portfolio size than an identical percentage decrease in the variables. The intuition is straightforward from the geometry of concave and convex functions, as depicted infigure A1. Infigure A1a, notice that, relative to a linear function, a concave PMB function gives rise to a smaller portfolio of entrepreneurial firms for a shift up in the PMC function from PMC0to PMC1(the size of the fund falls from EF0to EF1, where EF refers to entrepreneurial firms). The same shift in the PMC function would give rise to a smaller change in the portfolio for a linear PMB function (the size of the fund falls from EF0to EF3). The situation is different for a fall in the PMC function from PMC0to PMC2: the increase in the portfolio is larger for a linear PMB function (portfolio size increases to EF4) than for a concave function (portfolio size increases to EF2). Fig. A1.—
Comparative statics and nonlinearities

The effect of the convex PMC function relative to a linear PMC function is depicted infigure A1b. Analogously tofigure A1a, a decrease in PMB has a larger impact on portfolio size in the case in which PMC is concave (EF0to EF1) relative to the case in which PMC is linear (EF0to EF3); an increase in PMB has a smaller impact on portfolio size in which case in which PMC is concave (EF0to EF2) relative to the case in which PMC is linear (EF0to EF4).

The curvature of the PMB and PMC functions has implications for the econometric tests carried out in the paper. The implications are depicted infigure A2, where changes in the factors that shift the PMC and PMB functions are plotted against expected changes in the number of entrepreneurial firms in a VC fund portfolio. The relationship is concave. Decreases in the variables measured on the horizontal axis infigure A2have a greater impact on the number of entrepreneurial firms in the VC fund portfolio. This is consistent with the depiction of EF0to EF1relative to EF3in figuresA1aandA1b, given the concave shape of the PMB curve and convex shape of the PMC curve. Similarly, increases in the variables measured on the horizontal axis infigure A2have a smaller impact on portfolio size (compare the smaller move from EF0to EF2to the larger move from EF0to EF4in figs.A1aandA1b). Fig. A2.—
Nonlinearities in hypothesis tests

The convex shape of the cost function and concave shape of the PMC function imply diminishing returns to scale, as depicted infigure A2. In particular, I consider outputs of a VC fund as the number of entrepreneurial firms that are financed by the fund and inputs as the characteristics of the VC fund, characteristics of the entrepreneurial firm, the nature of the financing transaction, and market conditions.21The issue of returns to scale involves the question of how much outputs are changed when all the inputs are increased proportionately. If outputs rise by a smaller proportion than the increase in inputs, then returns to scale are diminishing, as depicted infigure A2. That is, there are decreasing returns to scale if doubling inputs leads to less than a doubling of outputs. Conversely, if outputs rise by a larger (the same) proportion than the increase in inputs, then returns to scale are increasing (constant). Whether or not returns to scale are increasing or decreasing is an empirical question that is assessed inSection IV. Note that the theory and evidence herein consider returns to scale in VC output production, not economies of scale in average costs.

It is impossible to predict a priori the precise extent to which nonlinearities may exist in the relation between proxies for costs and benefits to increasing portfolio size depicted infigure A2.22Indeed, the relations could even be convex. The empirical analysis inSection IVtherefore explores nonlinearities in the relation between the cost and benefit proxies discussed above and the size of the VC portfolio through the use of grid search and maximum likelihood optimization methods. To this end, I employ Box‐Cox regression methods (Box and Cox1964), which are a standard and well‐accepted methodology for accounting for the nonlinearities predicted by the theory and described in this appendix (and as discussed in, e.g., Davidson and MacKinnon [1993] and Abrevaya [2000]).

fn.p: For example, there may be benefits from overlapping VC effort and strategic alliances across investee firms with related technologies.

The concave shape of the PMB curve is analogous to the concave marginal price curve in standard microeconomic theory; similarly, the convex shape of the PMC curve (discussed below) is also analogous to convex marginal cost curves in standard microeconomic theory (see, e.g., Gwartney and Stroup1997, chap. 8).

For example, if there are five firms in the original portfolio, the opportunity costs of adding a sixth firm are the assistance and resources allocated to the sixth firm that would have been allocated to the original five firms; the opportunity costs of adding a seventh firm are the resources allocated to firm 7 that would have been allocated to firms 1–6 etc.
This statement presumes that the PMC curve is upward sloping and the PMB curve is downward sloping, as would be expected for most ranges in portfolio size.

The definition of an input and an output in the venture capital context is rather new and probably not free from debate. Similarly, the definition of inputs and outputs in the banking literature has been debated extensively (see Molyneux et al. [1996] and Berger and Humphrey [1997] for surveys).

In the related banking literature, e.g., there is little consensus in both theory and empirical evidence as to the extent of scale economies among banks (see Molyneux et al. [1996] and Berger and Humphrey [1997] for surveys).
